bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, January 9, 1954

div1.p: Truby discusses his health, a disagreement with Standlee over her book, and his ability to recollect Reed and members of his Board.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, January 9, 1954
div1.opener:
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
January 9, 1954
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thanks very much for your very nice letter of December 3, which
I should have answered long ago, but holiday conditions prevented.
As I told you, I think, in my last letter, Dr. Treanor's activi-
ties have been unavoidably slowed up by special work heaped upon
him by the PT Department which he had to take over at that time
due to the absence of his Chief. The holiday activities then
added to the slow up due to the fact that most all of the hospital
work was closed up. In the midst of it all I had a very favorable
reaction quite suddenly and the doctor said that this was the real
thing and there will be more to follow. But the improvement did
not seem to continue although he is still hopeful that it will as
all the defective muscles seem to be extremely strong and are
just ready to take over. I rather think he is right but you just
have to wait to find out. This “take-over” and reinforcement
of the exercises by the reflex centers is a wonderful process and
I feel sure we are making progress.

I hope your visit to Washington in February will enable to make
real progress in locating the small notebook which disappeared at
the time of Reed's death and I believe that you can convince
Mrs. Carroll that if she can find the little book it will add
very much to clearing up this matter and be all to the credit of
Dr. Carroll. It is known that the book was in Reed's desk at the
Army Medical School when he died. If the book should now turn up
it would show how carefully it was preserved by Dr. Carroll instead
of being lost and it will be all to his credit to get it cleared up
now.

I note that you have been asked to give a talk at Walter Reed
Hospital in February. I am not surprised for I got in bad, as you
know, with Mrs. Standlee in reviewing her book and laying stress
upon your qualifications to pass on all of these matters and bring
out the facts. I knew it would cause opposition from plenty of
people in Washington but she was inconsiderate in accepting your
views and so obstinate in her comeback to me that I was thoroughly
disturbed about it and came back in kind. She finally cut me off
of her list of correspondents and, as you know to keep you fully
posted on it, I furnished you with a complete record of all the
correspondence at the time it was written. So, if you have time
to read it, you will have all the details. Her husband has been
promoted in the meantime to a Major General in the Medical Corps
and of course I am in bad as you no doubt have heard, not only at
the Letterman but evidently in the SGO. My views apparently
carried no weight so I am telling you this because there must be
a definite reason for getting you to speak if it is on this subject.
I assure you my attitude was in no way intended to be malicious
and of course have had no intention of meddling with what is wanted.

I do feel though that you should be reminded that such a possibil-
ity may exist. I was asked for my views and recommendations and
give them my honest views. I have not written to anybody in
Washington about this matter and I do not know what they concluded
to do about any of my recommendations. Neither has anyone written
to me or discussed the matter with me in any way so I may be all
wrong in all of this. However, I've told you the situation so
you will know all that I know about it. I am usually very reticent
in discussing such subjects with anybody where it may appear like
meddling when it really isn't.

I assure you that I will promptly be able to make a personality
appraisal of Reed and members of his Board as soon as I feel in
condition to do it and that might be very soon. In your letter
of December 3 you suggested that you might be able to help me by
asking me a few leading questions. I think that would help because
one reason I felt inadequate to write such an appraisal was because
I could not, for instance, give you an exact statement of the
height, weight, color of the eyes, etc., of Reed. And while, of
course, I think I could make a very definite and almost perfect
cguess on most of such things they would not be facts. Naturally,
I have very definite views about certain of the characteristics
that were most outstanding in all of them and they would be of value.

I have not been a patient in the Letterman since I left there in
September 1952 except for a few days in August 1953 when I had
a severe fall which left me unconscious and they rushed me to the
hospital. While I was there I had a few tests made and that is all.
Just why you did not hear of my departure from the hospital I
do not remember.

I intended to write you in the letter which left here yesterday
but did not have time to cover all of these subjects.

With reference to what I said about my progress in paragraph 1 of
this letter, my case is evidently running its own course and is
not “clicking” as we expected. But while Treanor can not predict
anything definitely, we think it will assume its normal course in
due time.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Albert E. Truby Albert E. Truby
